text: And he said, Oh let not the Lord be angry, and I will speak yet but this once: Peradventure ten shall be found there. And he said, I will not destroy it for ten's sake.
text_kjv: And he said, Oh let not the Lord be angry, and I will speak yet but this once: Peradventure ten shall be found there. And he said, I will not destroy it for ten's sake.
text_niv: Then he said, “May the Lord not be angry, but let me speak just once more. What if only ten can be found there?”He answered, “For the sake of ten, I will not destroy it.”
text_esv: Then he said, “Oh let not the Lord be angry, and I will speak again but this once. Suppose ten are found there.” He answered, “For the sake of ten I will not destroy it.”
text_nlt: Finally, Abraham said, “Lord, please don’t be angry with me if I speak one more time. Suppose only ten are found there?” And the LORD replied, “Then I will not destroy it for the sake of the ten.”
text_msg: He wouldn't quit, "Don't get angry, Master—this is the last time. What if you only come up with ten?""For the sake of only ten, I won't destroy the city."
text_nasb: Then he said, 'Oh may the Lord not be angry, and I shall speak only this once; suppose ten are found there?' And He said, 'I will not destroy [it] on account of the ten.'
context: Genesis 18 recounts the visit of three men, two of whom are revealed to be angels, to Abraham. One of these visitors is God himself, who reaffirms the promise of a son to Sarah and reveals his intention to investigate the wickedness of Sodom and Gomorrah. Hospitality was paramount in ancient Near Eastern cultures. Abraham's eagerness to feed and care for these strangers highlights this important cultural value. The cities of Sodom and Gomorrah were notorious for their moral depravity, especially their sexual immorality, as evidenced in later chapters. The ancient Near East lacked modern police forces and judicial systems. Divine investigation and judgment were often seen as a direct intervention when human justice failed. Abraham’s bold intercession for Sodom reflects the importance of intermediaries in approaching deity in the ancient world. While individuals could pray, approaching God through respected figures like Abraham carried significant weight. Family and tribal loyalty were central to social structures. Abraham's concern for the righteous within Sodom, possibly including his nephew Lot, stems from this deep-seated value. The concept of corporate responsibility, where a whole community suffers for the sins of some, was prevalent. Abraham challenges this notion, arguing for individual justice or at least leniency based on the presence of righteous individuals. The bargaining between Abraham and God is unique in the Old Testament. It shows a degree of intimacy and perhaps also a reflection of ancient bargaining practices, where parties negotiate to find an acceptable outcome.
meaning: Genesis 18:32 reveals several profound theological truths about God and humanity. First, it demonstrates God's willingness to listen to human intercession. Abraham's persistence in pleading for Sodom shows that God values human prayer and is moved by it. God is not depicted as a distant, unapproachable deity but as one who engages in dialogue with his creation. Secondly, the verse highlights God's justice tempered with mercy. While God is righteous in his judgment against sin, he is also compassionate and willing to spare the wicked if even a small number of righteous individuals are present. This illustrates the tension between God's holiness and his love. Thirdly, it underscores the power of righteousness. Even a small group of righteous people can have a significant impact on the fate of a larger community. This suggests that righteousness is not merely a personal attribute but a force that can influence the world around us. Fourthly, the verse implies the importance of seeking justice and mercy for others. Abraham's intercession is not selfish; he pleads for the lives of others, demonstrating a love and concern that reflects God's own character. Finally, the fact that God agrees to Abraham's terms underscores his faithfulness to his promises. He is a God who keeps his word, even when it means showing mercy to those who deserve judgment. The absence of even ten righteous individuals ultimately highlights the depth of Sodom's depravity and justifies God's judgment, while also demonstrating the rarity and power of true righteousness.
application: Genesis 18:32 offers several powerful applications for modern Christians. First, it encourages persistent prayer. Abraham's repeated requests to God should inspire us to persevere in our prayers, even when we feel discouraged. We should not be afraid to boldly approach God with our needs and the needs of others, trusting that he hears and responds. Second, it challenges us to live righteously. The verse suggests that our righteousness can have a significant impact on the world around us. We should strive to live lives that are pleasing to God, knowing that our actions can influence the fate of our communities. Third, it calls us to intercede for others. Just as Abraham pleaded for Sodom, we should pray for the salvation and well-being of those around us, especially those who are lost or suffering. This means actively seeking opportunities to share the Gospel and to serve those in need. Fourth, it reminds us of God's mercy and justice. We should remember that God is both just and merciful, and that he desires to show compassion to those who are willing to repent. We should strive to reflect both of these qualities in our own lives, offering forgiveness and grace to others while also upholding justice and truth. Fifth, it inspires us to be agents of transformation. While Abraham's efforts ultimately failed to save Sodom, his example shows that even one person can make a difference. We should be willing to stand up for what is right, even when it is unpopular, and to work towards creating a more just and compassionate world. Finally, let us remember the importance of corporate responsibility and prayer. We should be proactive in praying for the moral and spiritual health of our communities and nations.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for your willingness to listen to our prayers and for your boundless mercy and compassion. Help us to be bold in our intercession for others, just as Abraham was. Give us the courage to approach you with our needs and the needs of those around us, trusting that you hear and respond. Fill us with your righteousness, that we may be a light to the world and influence those around us for good. Help us to reflect your justice and mercy in our own lives, offering forgiveness and grace to others while also upholding truth and righteousness. Lord, grant us the wisdom to discern your will and the strength to follow it. May we be agents of transformation in our communities, working towards a more just and compassionate world. We offer this prayer in the name of Jesus Christ, our Lord and Savior. Amen.

faqs.answer: Abraham's bargaining highlights his concern for the righteous in Sodom, likely including his nephew Lot. His persistence reveals his understanding of God's justice and mercy, hoping to appeal to God's compassion and potentially save the city from destruction if some righteous people are found.
faqs.question: Q1: Why did Abraham bargain with God?

faqs.answer: This verse reveals God's willingness to listen to human intercession and adjust his plans based on the presence of righteousness. It showcases his mercy and compassion, even in the face of widespread wickedness, as he is willing to spare the city if enough righteous individuals can be found.
faqs.question: Q2: What does this verse tell us about God's character?

faqs.answer: While we shouldn't literally bargain, Abraham's example encourages persistent prayer. It suggests approaching God with our concerns, appealing to his character, and trusting in his will, rather than demanding specific outcomes. Our prayers should be rooted in humility and faith.
faqs.question: Q3: Is it appropriate to 'bargain' with God in prayer today?

faqs.answer: This verse challenges the idea of corporate punishment. Abraham questions whether the righteous should suffer for the sins of the wicked, suggesting a more nuanced understanding of justice where individual righteousness can impact the fate of the whole community.
faqs.question: Q4: What does this verse mean for the concept of corporate responsibility?

faqs.answer: The text doesn't explicitly say why God stopped at ten. It could symbolize a minimum number required to redeem a community, reflecting the importance of even a small remnant of righteousness. Ultimately, the lack of even ten righteous individuals highlights Sodom's deep-seated corruption.
faqs.question: Q5: Why did God stop at ten righteous people?
